front_matter: Z, z, was perhaps a letter of the original Latin alphabet, since it is found in the Carmen Saliare, Varr. L. L. 7, § 26 Müll.; and in a Latin record of an Oscan law of the time of the Gracchi, C. I. L. 1, 197; but it had long disappeared, when, in Cicero's time, it again came into use, but only in transcribing Greek names, to represent the Greek *z, z, which had previously been represented, when initial, by
senses: s, as in Saguntum for *za/kunqos, Sethus, sona, etc.; and by ss when medial, as in Atticisso, badissas, etc., in Plautus. It seems to have been sounded like the Engl. z (Corss. Ausspr. 1, p. 295; but cf. Roby, Gr. 1, § 195). In late Latin writings z is very frequent in place of s, and in the words Zmyrna for Smyrna, zmaragdus for smaragdus, is found in the best MSS. In writings of the third and fourth Christian centuries z often stands for initial di before a vowel, as zaconus, zabulus, etc.; cf. the Aeolic za/ for dia/.
one of the tribes of Israel, Juvenc. 1, 441; cf. Vulg. Apoc. 7, 8.

front_matter: Zābŭlus or Zābŏlus, i, m., = *za/bolos (collat. form of *dia/bolos; cf. the letter D
senses: init.), the Devil, Lact. Mort. Pers. 16.
i short, Juvenc. 1, 29; Paul. Nol. 5, 27; Sid. Carm. 16, 36), = *zaxari/as, Zacharias, the father of St. John the Baptist, Vulg. Luc. 1, 5; 1, 12; 1, 13; 3, 2; Lact. 4, 14, 6.

an island in the Ionian Sea, now Zante or Zacyntho, Mel. 2, 7, 10; Plin. 4, 12, 19, § 54; Liv. 21, 7; 26, 24; Verg. A. 3, 270; Plaut. Merc. 3, 4, 62; Ov. H. 1, 87 al.—Hence, Zăcynthĭus, a, um, adj., of or belonging to Zacynthus, Zacynthian: Calchas,Plaut. Merc. 5, 2, 104: bitumen,Plin. 35, 15, 51, § 178.
a lawgiver of the Locrians, Cic. Att. 6, 1, 18; id. Leg. 1, 22, 57; 2, 6, 14; Sen. Ep. 90, 5.
A small town in Numidia (now Zamra), celebrated for the victory gained there by Scipio over Hannibal, Liv. 30, 29; Sil. 3, 261 al.—

Another town in Numidia, also, with the addition regia, the residence of Juba, now Jama, Sall. J. 57 sq.; Auct. B. Afr. 91; Inscr. Grut. 364, 1.—Hence, Zămensis, e, adj., of or belonging to Zama: oppidum,i. e. Zama,Plin. 5, 4, 4, § 30 (al. Ziamensis). —As subst.: Zămenses, ĭum, m., the inhabitants of Zama, Auct. B. Afr. 92.

front_matter: zāmĭa (sāmĭa; cf. Fleck. Ep. Crit. 12), ae, f., = zhmi/a,
senses: hurt, damage, loss (cf. detrimentum), Plaut. Aul. 2, 2, 20.
a Thracian philosopher, App. Mag. p. 290, 9.

front_matter: zancha, zanca, or zanga, ae, f.,
senses: a kind of soft Parthian shoe, Gallien. ap. Treb. Claud. 17; Cod. Th. 14, 10, 2.
an older name of the city of Messana (Messina), in Sicily, Ov. M. 14, 5; 15, 290; Sil. 1, 662.—Hence,
Zanclaeus, a, um, adj., of or belonging to Zancle, Zanclean: harena,i. e. Sicily,Ov. M. 13, 729.—
Zanclēĭus, a, um, adj., of Zancle, Zanclean: moenia,i. e. Messana,Sil. 14, 48: saxa,Ov. M. 14, 47.
a yellow gem, Plin. 37, 10, 70, § 185.
very rich, Petr. 37.
A kind of grain, spelt: Triticum spelta, Linn. (pure Lat. alica); Plin. 18, 8, 19, § 81 sq.; Hier. in Isa. 9, 28, 25; id. in Ezech. 4, 9.—
A kind of rosemary, App. Herb. 97.
zealously (late Lat.), Ven. Fort. Vit. Patern. 3.
a zealous person, a zealot, Ven. Carm. 5, 6, 12; Ambros. in Psa. 51, 15.

front_matter: zēlĭvĭra, ae, f., a false read. for caelibi, Tert. Exhort. Cast. 9.

senses: To love with zeal or ardently (eccl. Lat.): populum summo pietatis amore,Tert. Carm. adv. Marc. 4, 36; Aug. Conf. 1, 7.—
To be jealous of: non zeles mulierem sinus tui,Vulg. Ecclus. 9, 1.—
To be zealous for: zelat zelum legis,Vulg. 1 Macc. 2, 58.—Also in dep. form: zelatus est legem. Vulg. 1 Macc. 2, 26.—Absol.: zelatus est pro Deo suo,Vulg. Num. 25, 13.
one that loves with jealousy, one that is jealous (eccl. Lat.); of God,Tert. adv. Marc. 1, 28; 4, 25; Vulg. Exod. 20, 5 al.
jealousy, Plin. 25, 7, 37, § 75; Vulg. Num. 5, 14 (in Cic. Tusc. 4, 8, 18, and Att. 10, 8, A, 1, written as Greek).
jealous: larba,Juv. 5, 45: moechae,id. 6, 278.—As substt.
zēlŏtypus, i, m., a jealous man, Petr. 45; Quint. 4, 2, 30; Mart. 1, 93, 13.—
zēlŏtypa, ae, f., a jealous woman, Petr. 69.
zeal, emulation; jealousy, Vitr. 7 praef.; Prud. Ham. 188; Aus. Epigr. 77; Hier. in Gal. 2, 4, vv. 17, 18; Vulg. Num. 25, 11.

front_matter: zĕma or zŭma, ătis, n., = ze/ma,
senses: a cooking utensil, a saucepan, Apic. 8, 1 fin.; Val. ap. Treb. Claud. 14; Serv. ad Verg. A. 3, 466.
the name of several Greek philosophers.

The founder of the Stoic school, a native of Cittium in Cyprus; form Zeno, Varr. R. R. 2, 1, 3; Cic. Fin. 3, 2, 5; 3, 4, 15; id. N. D. 2, 22, 57; Sen. Ben. 4, 39, 1; Quint. 2, 20, 7; form Zenon,Cic. Tusc. 5, 9, 27 B. and K.; Sen. Ep. 33, 7.—
An Eleatic philosopher of Elea, in Magna Groecia, Cic. Ac. 2, 42, 129; id. Tusc. 2, 22, 52; id. N. D. 3, 33, 82.—
An Epicurean philosopher, the teacher of Cicero and Atticus, Cic. Fin. 1, 5, 16; id. N. D. 1, 21, 59; 1, 33, 93 sq.; id. Tusc. 3, 17, 38.—
A Greek emperor in the fifth Christian century.—Hence, Zēnōnĭānus, a, um, adj., of or pertaining to the emperor Zeno, Zenonian: lex,Just. Inst. 3, 2, 3.
a queen of Palmyrene, wife of Odenatus, conquered by Aurelian, Treb. Poll. XXX. Tyrann. 14, 23; 14, 29; Vop. Aurel. 22 sq.; Eutr. 9, 9.—
Daughter of Mithridates, king of Armenia, Tac. A. 12, 44; 13, 6; 13, 37.
an island near Crete, Mel. 2, 7; Plin. 4, 12, 20, § 61.
the Zephyritide, an appellation of Arsinoë, wife of Ptolemaeus Philadelphus, who was honored as a goddess, Cat. 66, 57 (cf. Plin. 34, 14, 42, § 148).
of or belonging to a zephyr or to the west wind: ova,i. e. wind-eggs, addle-eggs,Plin. 10, 60, 80, § 167.
a gentle west wind, the western breeze, zephyr (pure Lat. Favonius); personified, son of Astroeus  and Aurora.
Poet., in gen., wind, Verg. A. 4, 562.
a precious stone, otherwise unknown, Plin. 37, 9, 53, § 138 (al. leros).
of or belonging to the Thracian town of Zerynthus, Zerynthian: litora,Ov. Tr. 1, 10, 19: Apollo,Liv. 38, 41.
init.
the Greek letter zeta, Aus. Idyll. Lit. Monos. 12, 11.

front_matter: zētārĭus, a, um, = diaetarius, Paul. Sent. 3, 6, 58.

senses: a brother of Calăis and son of Boreas, one of the Argonauts, Ov. M. 6, 716; Prop. 1, 20, 26.—Collat. form Zētus, i, n., Serv. ad Verg. A. 10, 350.
a son of Jupiter by Antiopa, and brother of Amphion, Cic. de Or. 2, 37, 155; id. Rep. 1, 18, 30; Auct. Her. 2, 27, 43; Hor. Ep. 1, 18, 42; Hyg. Fab. 76 and 155.
a very fruitful district in Africa, now the northern part of Tunis, Plin. 5, 4, 3, § 23; Mart. Cap. 6, § 669.—Called Zeugis, Isid. 14, 5, 8.
a kind of reed, Plin. 16, 36, 66, § 169.
a grammatical figure, according to which two nouns or two infinitives are united to a verb which is applicable to only one of them, Ascon. ad Cic. Verr. 1, 18.
a town in Syria, on the Euphrates, now Rumkaleh, Plin. 5, 12, 13, § 67; 5, 24, 21, § 86; 34, 15, 43, § 150; Tac. A. 12, 12; Luc. 8, 237; Stat. S. 3, 2, 137.
a kind of fish (pure Lat. faber), Col. 8, 16, 9; Plin. 9, 18, 32, § 68.

front_matter: Zeuxis, is and ĭdis (acc. -im or -in), m., = *ceu=cis.
senses: A famous Greek painter of Heraclea, Plin. 35, 10, 36, § 65 sq.; Cic. Brut. 18, 70; id. de Or. 3, 7, 26; acc. Zeuxin, id. Inv. 2, 1, 1.—
Zeuxis Blandenius (a native of Blandos, a city of Phrygia), a matricide, Cic. Q. Fr. 1, 2, 2, § 4 sq.

front_matter: zingĭbĕri or zimpĭbĕri, indecl. n., = ziggi/beri,
senses: ginger: Amomum zingiber, Linn.; Plin. 12, 7, 14, § 27.—Also zingĭ-ber, ĕris, n., Cels. 5, 23 fin.; Pall. Oct. 20, 2; Apic. 2, 2.
a kind of gnat (rustic Lat.; cf. Span. zenzalo; Ital. zanzara),Cassiod. in Psa. 104, 31.

front_matter: zinzĭlŭlo, āre, v. n., the natural cry of certain birds,
senses: to chirp (of the regulus, merops, and progne), Auct. Carm. Phil. 43.
the caul, omentum, Apic. 8, 6 fin.
darnel, cockle, tares (eccl. Lat.), Prud. Apoth. 6, 8; Vulg. Matt. 13, 25; 13, 26 sq.; Ambros. in Luc. 8, 49.

front_matter: zīzyphum or zīzĭphum, i, n., = zi/zufon,

senses: the jujube-tree, Col. 9, 4, 3; Pall. 5, 4.
init.
a precious stone, otherwise unknown, Plin. 37, 10, 70, § 185.
an aromatic plant, a kind of mint, Plin. 19, 10, 57, § 176.

front_matter: Zmyrna and Zmyrnaeus, a, um, v. Smyrn-.

senses: the zodiac (pure Lat. orbis signifer), Cic. Arat. 317; Gell. 13, 9, 6.—Hence, zōdĭăcus, a, um, adj., of the zodiac: zodiacum diastema,Sid. Ep. 8, 11: zodiacus tractus,Mart. Cap. 1, § 44: zodiaca hospitia,id. ib. 1, § 5.
one of the Aeons of Valentinus, Tert. adv. Valent. 12.

a severe critic in the time of Ptolemaeus Philadelphus, a censurer of Homer (hence called *(omhroma/stic, Homeromastix), Vitr. 7 praef.— Transf., of a censorious person, Ov. R. Am. 366; Mart. 11, 37, 1.
a dish of fish stewed in their own liquor, Apic. 4, 2, § 147 dub.

front_matter: zōna (sōna, Plaut. Merc. 5, 2, 85 Ritschl), ae, f., = zw/nh,
senses: a belt, girdle, zone, worn about the loins by women (cf. cingulum).
Transf.
A girdle worn by men for containing money, a money-belt (cf. crumena), C. Gracch. ap. Gell. 15, 12 fin.; Hor. Ep. 2, 2, 40.—
The girdle or belt of Orion, a constellation, Ov. F. 6, 787.—
A line running around the edge of a gem, a girdle, Plin. 37, 6, 24, § 90.—

One of the imaginary circles which divided the earth into five climates, a zone, Verg. G. 1, 233; Ov. M. 1, 46; 2, 131; Plin. 2, 68, 68, § 172; Mel. 1, 1, 2; Macr. Somn. Scip. 1, 15, 13; 2, 5, 20; Mart. Cap. 6, § 602.—
A kind of herpes or erysipelas, which spreads about the body like a girdle, and destroys life, the shingles; called also zoster, Scrib. Comp. 63.
of or belonging to a zone (of the earth): ambitus,Macr. Somn. Scip. 2, 5 med.
of or belonging to a belt or girdle.
Adj.: sector,a cutpurse,Plaut. Trin. 4, 2, 20.—
Subst.: zōnārĭus, ii, m., a maker of girdles, Cic. Fl. 7, 17; Lucil. ap. Non. p. 2, 379 (Sat. Fr. 30, 16).
round about, in a circle, Lucil. ap. Non. p. 189, 33.
a promontory of Thrace, opposite to Thasos, Mel. 2, 2; Plin. 4, 11, 18, § 43.
a little girdle, Cat. 61, 53; Seren. ap. Non. p. 539, 19; Lampr. Alex. Sev. 52.
the frieze of a column (between the epistylium and the coronis), Vitr. 3, 5, 10; 4, 1, 2.
great houseleek, called also aizoum majus, Plin. 25, 13, 102, § 160.
pitch mixed with wax, which was scraped off from ships, Plin. 16, 12, 23, § 56; 24, 7, 26, § 41.
a plant, called also clinopodion, Plin. 24, 15, 87, § 137.
A celebrated physiognomist, Cic. Fat. 5, 10; id. Tusc. 4, 37, 80.—
A Persian noble, who mutilated himself and thereby helped to conquer Babylon, Just. 1, 10, 15.—
A rhetorician, Quint. 3, 6, 3.—Hence, perh.,
Zōpyrion, Lucil. ap. Non. p. 210, 28.—
Zōpyriātim, adv., in the manner of Zopyrus, Lucil. ap. Non. p. 455, 17.
a precious stone, otherwise unknown, Plin. 37, 10, 70, § 185.

Zoroaster, a lawgiver of the Medes, Just. 1, 1, 9; Plin. 30, 1, 2, § 3; App. Mag. p. 291.—Hence, Zōrŏ-astrēus, a, um, adj., of or belonging to Zoroaster, Zoroastrian: susurri,i. e. magical,Prud. Apoth. 494 (where Zŏr-, by solecism).
A kind of herpes, the shingles (cf. zona, II. E.), Plin. 26, 11, 74, § 121.—
A kind of sca shrub (called also prason), Plin. 13, 25, 48, § 135.
a promontory, town, and harbor of Attica; the promontory is now called C. Lombarda, Cic. Att. 5, 12 init.
A little private chamber, closet, or cabinet, for reposing in by day (cf. conclave), Plin. Ep. 2, 17, 21; cf. zothecula.—
A recess, niche, for religious purposes, Inscr. Orell. 1368; 2006; 3889.
a little closet or cabinet, Plin. Ep. 5, 6, 38; Sid. Ep. 8, 16; 9, 11.
the seed of the Christ's-thorn (paliurus), Plin. 24, 13, 71, § 115.

front_matter: zygĭa, ae, f., = zugi/a (prop. an adj. from zu/gios, belonging to or fit for yokes).
senses: A tree, called also carpinus, horn-beam: Carpinus betulus, Linn.; Plin. 16, 15, 26, § 67.—
Zygia tibia, a nuptial or marriage flute, App. M. 4, p. 157, 37.
a name of Juno, as the goddess of marriage, App. M. 6, p. 174, 38.
wild thyme, App. Herb. 99.
the office of a weigh-master, Cod. Th. 15, 26, 1.
a master of the weights, weigh-master, Cod. Th. 12, 7, 2; Cod. Just. 10, 71, 2.
a kind of malt-liquor among the Egyptians, Plin. 22, 25, 82, § 164; Col. 10, 116; Dig. 33, 6, 9 praef.
